title: When will Fitch, Moody's, or S&P next downgrade the United Kingdom's long-term local or foreign currency issuer ratings?
preds: S&P and Fitch just signaled that the UK, for now, is stable. Everyone is watching to see what happens next. There is unlikely to be an rating changes.
With a continuation of the current leadership it seems hard to imagine what would justify a change in rating decision.
+4% to 'not before' due to time decay.

Not before January but maybe at some point next year? Per the Economist:
“Whoever wins the general election on December 12th will have reason to worry about the economy. Purchasing managers’ indices aim to take the pulse of business, and for now they point to an economy on the slide. Monday’s manufacturing data and Tuesday’s construction survey showed both those industries contracting. Today it was the turn of the all-important service sector, supposedly the economy’s great strength. It was equally gloomy; new orders fell at their fastest pace since mid 2016. PMIs in Britain tend to overshoot on both the downside and upside. In July 2016, immediately after the Brexit referendum, they pointed towards an imminent recession which never arrived. They are still worth watching though. And the picture they paint is consistent with other data sources and most forecasters. Brexit and wider political uncertainty are holding back investment, and growth looks likely to be under 1.5% next year. That will keep the public finances under pressure, leaving less room for the giveaways that all parties are pledging.”

Elections will likely elect the same government that got the current deal. A vote before Christmas is possible, but I don’t think the deal in current state is enough to trigger a downgrade. The Brexit Party all but stepping aside raises the probability a downgrade is avoided this year
Even if Tories don’t get in, thinking Corby won’t have enough time to declare a workers paradise by year end.

UK has been plowing its money into official US paper and has jumped to #3 on the monthly Treasury TIC data list just out on 15 Nov. Only China and Japan hold more dollar instruments than London. Tis the season and since its likely that former US-UK dual national (renounced US citizenship couple years ago) Boris Johnson will remain PM, the US-based agencies prolly won't take action until after the New Year.
With the delay in Brexit, I don't think the ratings agencies will update their ratings until there is more clarity.

https://www.bbc.com/news/business-50361025
Moving a bit on this one, since Moody's has finally noticed that the UK has been ungoverned, or at least unled, for at least several years.
..... ok I'm going to stick with my guns  - the GE being too close to end of 2019 to change much - so despite poor outlook from Moody's I'm re-adjusting.

I was stronger on the 'not before 2020' bin   - but now updating because of GE and noting that all government contenders are promising vast increases in public spending.   Coupled with the currently somewhat stalled economy and uncertainty as to any future trading deals,  Moody's have changed their outlook from stable to negative which reflects the direction of play throughout December and into the new year.

Yields and CDS prices remain low, but all three agencies released some interesting forward guidance. Brexit uncertainty and growing government debt with little ability to generate more revenue are driving the outlook lower. Ultimately, I think most of the money (traders, assets managers, hedge funds, etc) are looking at currencies and U.K. debt to bet on Brexit. If they aren’t concerned, I’m not as concerned, but I am more concerned than I was yesterday.  https://www.wsj.com/articles/brexit-paralysis-leads-moodys-to-lower-outlook-on-u-k-debt-11573294346?emailToken=6f4ead7bc9f3150bfbd99572751cf74fVIefLEGkECTELEHQreCIXCHnjNB8fgpNYr53q2uSTGAL066C0N5I7IUvEhlN+5RXI/uydYmyPLEEC3XY2b9RnPZu5r/2iAcyPS+8t17D1IMPrmQ/7uBwtjS//sopUEin&reflink=article_copyURL_share
simply does not seem there's a reason to do so given A50 extension and rating agencies being conservative, after-the-fact downgraders.

It looks like as long as the Brexit can keeps getting kicked down the road there won't be a downgrade. And all indications are that the can is being kicked down the road until Jan 1. PredictIt has those odds at 98%. So I'm adjusting that down to reflect other unknown (by me) factors that could cause a downgrade.

Fitch completes april 26/oct18 
Moody completed reviews dec 2018, Mar 9, May17 , June, July, Aug, Nov 8, , and therefore the most likely to downgrade. 
S&P Apr 26,  Oct 25 So the only scheduled review is moodies; and atm what is there to review except an impending election.
Will probably only happen if Labour win the GE which is currently looking very unlikely.
Adjusting down given the passage of time and the deal extension through Jan 31. Risks still remain if an earlier vote is particularly damaging to the UK

The under-review 90-day A50 extension (President Macron's objection notwithstanding) would seem to argue for a maintenance of the rating, not a diminishment.
4% chance reflects that Macron might gum-up the works with his opinion for a mere 15-day extension.
Shifting toward 2020, much like Brexit itself.

Extend is starting to become my base case given EU comments about the latest proposal. Johnson also seems to be locked into a deal or extension and a deal seems less likely given the backstop concerns.  Ratings agencies seem to be committed to not reacting to uncertainty, but rather hard events. Only a slight adjustment, though, since it’s hard to say in such a volatile environment

The pound has made a strong move to the euro over the past 40 days as the outlook for "Extend" seems to be getting clearer.
A stable-to-stronger pound suggests no ratings downgrade.
If we get a hard brexit, there will be a serious downgrade. If it's held off, nothing much will happen.
I think the UK will leave the EU at the end of October which will cause great harm to its economy.
Time left for a downgrade is running out but it is certain. This Brexit will end in tears. Mark my words. Downgrade 100%.
Hard Brexit is becoming less likely and the British budget is actually starting to balance

Ratings stooges are aware of the impact they can have and will probably stay quiet until 1Q2020. Loss of things like trans shipping markets through Ireland etc.. will move the needle overnight but the dust has to explode before it can settle. It will take years to process the outcomes of this and effects on the new London-State economy.

[A bit late to the party on this one]  First two are now past therefore narrowed to two later options - with current timeline suggesting 31st October as date for UK exit from EU & with no practical alternative to No Deal = UK leaves on 31st Oct Next few weeks will add more to consider - will Lab, Lib Dem et al form alternative govt - will Boris Johnson manage to achieve a deal with EU at the last minute and then achieve the numbers to get the vote through parliament? Or will Johnson drive through a no deal and opt for a general election. On existing path I suggest UK will crash out because the EU will not help Johnson by improving the withdrawl agreement - if status quo remains potential downgrade would happen after 31st Oct - to be reviewed
Raising the chance of it happening before 31 December from 35% after the Queen agreed to let Johnson prorogue Parliament, raising the chances of a no-deal Brexit.
UK in early Spring (past Winter crises), Summer begins ~2025. Commercial traders extremely long GBP, suggesting lows are in and a Sterling bull (capital inflows) ahead.
Prorogation of parliament changes things, pound dropping even further, downgrade looks increasingly likely to fall sooner than I originally anticipated if at all.

If a No Deal Brexit occurs, ratings agencies will have no choice but to downgrade the value of sterling resulting from increased risk of government borrowing and lack of access to the EU market. This will be a reactionary rather than an anticipatory move.

Brexit uncertainty likely to rumble on into next year - when Brexit slow-down will start to bite in figures.
Right now and on the time-line in question uncertainty itself will cause postponement of any change to outlook.
Updating. Now more of a possibility with the uncertainty over Brexit and the fall of £

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-08-21/u-k-budget-deficit-soars-as-britain-prepares-for-brexit
https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/uk-government-borrowing-surges-ahead-of-brexit-deadline-1.3992834 The budget deficit between April and July stood at £16 billion, 60 per cent more than the same period last year, Office for National Statistics figures published Wednesday show. Borrowing is rising much more quickly than budget officials forecast in March as revenue from taxes fails to keep pace with spending, a possible sign that the economic downturn in the second quarter is taking a toll. That’s an unwelcome fiscal inheritance for prime minister Boris Johnson, who has promised £20 billion of tax cuts plus extra money for policing, health care and schools. The public finances could take a further £30 billion hit if he sees through his threat to let Britain crash out of the European Union without a deal on October 31st, forecasters estimate. Years of post-crisis austerity have brought down the deficit from almost 10 per cent of GDP in 2009-10, the highest in peacetime history, to a 17-year low of just 1.1 per cent last year. July is typically a good month for the public finances, as the Treasury benefits from larger-than-normal tax payments.

The chance of a no-deal Brexit has risen.  Survey of banks place it at 30%. Additionally we have to consider the possibility of a credit rating cut without a no-deal Brexit. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-08-09/pound-falling-to-parity-is-an-idea-that-s-starting-to-take-hold

...Early insights into the government’s fiscal and economic strategy raise questions about its commitment to repaying debt from the 2007-08 financial crisis, the rating agency said. But it stressed that it was still early days and that new Prime Minster Boris Johnson’s policy ambitions have yet to be followed up with measures. Moody's said the period leading to the next government budget announcement in October or November should provide more detail. "The new UK government has made tax and spending promises over recent weeks in the context of a challenging growth and debt environment," said Sarah Carlson, a senior vice president at Moody's and co-author of the report.
https://www.thenational.ae/world/brexit/british-government-s-brexit-stance-could-weaken-its-credit-profile-moody-s-warns-1.893662 prev:
(https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-02-20/u-k-rating-may-be-cut-amid-risk-of-no-deal-brexit-fitch-says)
(https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-ratings/sp-and-fitch-warn-uk-rating-still-at-risk-from-a-no-deal-brexit-idUKKCN1S228Y)
(https://www.ft.com/content/14622ec4-3562-11e9-bd3a-8b2a211d90d5)
Shifting five points toward it happening this year because I think a no-deal Brexit has gotten much likelier given recent political events in the UK.

Moody’s released a research note on 7/2 that considered the risks of Brexit against the strong economy (their words not mine). The note ends with a conclusion that a no deal Brexit could lead to a downgrade.  Scenarios for Brexit are almost endless and just because Johnson doesn’t seem amenable to deal now, doesn’t mean he won’t be. Right now the EU doesn’t have much incentive to negotiate and the lack of unity in Parliment makes any changes to the current deal less certain. As a result, I’m pulling my probably for a downgrade in the last two months of the year up. I’ll temper that with the fact that an extension or uncertainty about the impacts could prompt Moody’s to pause on any changes until 2020.
The "bad news" is already taken into account in the current rating
These Financial Institutions are relatively Conservative. But it must happen, ofcourse
Simply because the Brexit mess will not be resolved by then in any direction.
Likelihood of no deal brexit has increased.
I think the agencies will be cautious
If we leave during with no deal economy will tank and if eu settlement withheld credit rating will plummet
Because they can see the quality of UK political/economic leadership.
The FTSE 100 has been very resilient to the uncertainty around brexit.
Shifting a few points later in the year since nothing seems likely before July 31st.
Equating this to the probability of a no deal Brexit based on my analysis on Brexit questions.
Not before the negative fiscal effects of brexit begin to show clearly.

If you look at monthly US Treasury TIC data, UK is now #3 holder of official US paper after Chine and Japan, now surpassing Brazil and Ireland.  The trans-Atlantic partnership strengthened Trump friend Boris is likely to have at least six months wiggle room to hold off the ratings agencies and their agendas. Just a shot in the dark.

Fitch have had the UK on negative watch since Feb 2019 due to the risk of a no-deal brexit but that risk has now gone away. "The vote of confidence follows warnings from the three top ratings agencies that the UK would be downgraded in the event of a disorderly Brexit." [1] Current UK credit rating [2]; Feb 20 2019	AA	Fitch - negative watch
Sep 22 2017	Aa2	Moody's - stable
Jun 28 2016	AA	Fitch - negative
Jun 27 2016	AA	S&P - negative Crowd: 3%, 6%, 28%, 63%. [1] https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/britain-could-survive-no-deal-brexit-with-aaa-rating-intact-7m8ck2bpj
[2] https://tradingeconomics.com/united-kingdom/rating

Credit rating agencies tend to move cautiously on their ratings for the major sovereigns, including the UK.  Prior to 2013, the UK ratings had been unchanged by any agency for decades [1].  Following the Brexit vote in 2016, all three rating agencies have already downgraded the UK :  S&P and Fitch within days of the referendum vote, while Moody's didn't downgrade until over a year later (useful table and charts here [2]).  Fitch indicated in February 2019 that they might make a change if a "hard Brexit" occurs [3]. Given the history, I think it is unlikely that they change their ratings again until the Brexit issue is finally resolved with the EU.  Recently, the UK negotiated an extension on that decision until 31 October 2019, avoiding a hard Brexit. Given the lengthy process with little progress over almost three years, I am skeptical that any progress is made on the Brexit negotiations until closer to that deadline, with some chance that it even gets pushed once again.   So, the core of my forecast is that there will be no Brexit or at least a smooth Brexit before 2020, leading to no further downgrades in ratings.  The chance of a hard Brexit rises as the October deadline approaches with no deal, which would likely cause an immediate downgrade. [1] https://www.bbc.com/news/business-21554311
[2] https://countryeconomy.com/ratings/uk
[3] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/02/20/fitch-may-cut-uks-aa-rating-on-brexit-uncertainty.html
Updating, lowering second bucket because a no deal Brexit before 31 July has become less likely.
Shifting later to reflect Brexit delays.
Brexit : Unintended consequences and collateral damage Don't forget, It was all  "Call me Dave"s doing
Brexit fallout. Either successful or unsuccessful.

Shifting later because there are only a few days left for the first bucket.
As long as their is Brexit extension, they'll wait.

• S&P: AA (Negative), AA

Shifting later in the year given the uncertainty and the probability that Brexit will be delayed.

Fitch may cut UK's 'AA' rating on Brexit uncertainty
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brexit-fitch/fitch-may-cut-uks-aa-rating-on-brexit-uncertainty-idUSKCN1Q92ZG?il=0 I believe the other two will probably follow.

I estimate possible outcomes on or before the 29th of March as hard Brexit (25%), Brexit with a last-minute deal (25%), Brexit being delayed (40%) or Brexit being aborted (10%).  I think a downgrade is quite likely to occur soon after the 29th of March in the 'hard Brexit' case, but with a deal or delay there's a smaller chance of a downgrade and it could be sooner or later (or beyond in 2020).  I think it's unlikely to occur before the 29th of March, because if they were going to make a move based on uncertainty they would have done so already. That this question is looking for a downgrade of any one of several ratings inflates my numbers.  But they still look somewhat optimistic because they hide the substantial chance (in particular if there's a deal or delay) of a downgrade occurring but not until things have played out in 2020 or beyond.

Adjusting pre-March, 30th probability down, given comments from all 3 agencies on a wait-and-see approach. A Sept Moody's note (https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-No-deal-Brexit-would-damage-UKs-economic-and-fiscal--PR_388844) seems to suggest a similar approach if the UK leaves without a deal - though risks would be significantly higher on the downside. I can't find anything to suggest a shifting view.  I'm pulling my 8/19 - 1/20 probability down because I think the agencies will see what kind of deal the UK can get in extended negotiations. The post-1/20 bucket got a lift, based on the chance that lawmakers are playing chicken to see who will get the most concessions, but it is unlikely they'll take the country into 2020 without a deal. I still think a market reaction to a hard landing would crush the pound and govt bonds, increase inflation, and force the rating agency's hand - that is why I'm increasing the 3/19 - 7/19 bucket as well.
Updating to account for updated forecast about Brexit timing and possible extension: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/827143

In almost all cases ratingare not a leading indicator of a worse creditworthiness, but follow  the market risk spreads. Actaally, risk spreads have widened significantly over 2018, but are sill low by historical standards. Thus, currently the market indicate no downgrade. However, it is of course totally possible that risk spreads will widen due to a chaos Brexit and in fact, I expect a no-deal Brexit and a recession in the UK, but I currently do not think that this will be enough to harm the UK and endanger government debt payments so much that a rating downgrade would be justified.  
A main difference between the UK and many other economis is, that the UK is indebted more or less only in its own currency, so that even a strong exchange rate fluctuation does not lead to a rise of real debt.
This is my read of Goldman's statement yesterday: http://fortune.com/2019/01/30/goldman-sachs-no-deal-brexit-odds/ Assuming Brexit would be delayed until after 7/31 but before 12/31.
As the 29 Mar 19 exit dates becomes more unlikely a downgrade does too. UK will either be out of the EU with the current deal signed or still in as at 31 Dec 19.

A downgrade would happen if the UK leaves the EU (extremely unlikely) or there's a general election (possible) followed by a Labour win (coin-toss). Markets have priced-in a delay of article 50, but for how long?

They aren't going to do anything until Brexit is resolved. I suspect that issue will continue to draw on and ultimately lead to elections and referendums. Not anytime soon though. Going to hedge a bit though.

Well, May survived the No Confidence Vote which makes things a bit tricky. Sentiment for a second referendum seems to be gaining steam outside of Parliament, and British companies are stockpiling inventory. To me there seems to be a lot of deadlock which would lead me to increase the probability of leaving without a deal. That being said, I think I was wrong to tie a No Deal Brexit on March 29th with a downgrade before the 30th.  The question becomes interesting because of how long the ratings agencies will wait. I think, however, the sharp devaluation in the pound that would accompany a hard Brexit would force their hand sooner rather than later.

With monetary stimulus pouring in, not seeing serious global recession until H1'20. Hedging H2'19 on the off-chance that heavy fiscal stimulus is deemed necessary (drawing a downgrade), following a Q3'19 bloodbath in financial markets..
Updating after May won the no confidence vote today

Bank downgrades or outlook revisions could be triggered if the UK’s exit from Europe is chaotic, rating agency says

I think that the economic risks around Brexit have increased dramatically due to the events in parliament today. With that I think the risk of a downgrade has grown too, either once it becomes clear that the UK with crash out or based on the disruption that occurs immediately after.

Updating, same decision tree as in https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/800096 , but adjusting 
a) deal Brexit as scheduled: 22% (down 13%)
b) no-deal brexit as scheduled: 10% (down 10%)
c) deal Brexit delayed: 60% (up 30%)
d) no-deal Brexit delayed: 3% (down 7%)
e) UK revokes announcement to leave EU according to Article 50: 5% (unchanged) Leaving the next level of the tree the same as outlined previously give me the forecast.
There will be economic downturn from leaving EU and the uncertainty felt in 2018
Uncertainty is highest in the next few weeks but will not end.
Because of the unrest in the region. And President Trump's decision to remove troops from Syria
rating agencies are corrupt, most junk debt in thr US is rated BBB, ask Goldman Sachs this question, they run the Whitehouse and UK governments for now....and mean ONLY for now
Need to acquire more debt or open up larger deficit
I can see the agencies coming out early to add to the pressure for a soft Brexit instead of a no deal.

Before Mar 30 only seems likely if there is a hard Brexit, which seems unlikely but possible. Based on the general chaos and slow growth the country right now and after Brexit I think they will struggle and there is a real risk they will be downgraded because of the economic risks.

Since this is a timing question taking my adjusted forecast for what will happen with regards to Article 50 and Brexit as a baseline for Brexit timing: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/800092
One other important factor influencing whether there will be a downgrade is whether there will be a deal or no-deal Brexit. For on schedule/delayed and deal or no-deal I estimate:
a) deal Brexit as scheduled: 35%
b) no-deal brexit as scheduled: 20%
c) deal Brexit delayed: 30%
d) no-deal Brexit delayed: 10%
e) UK revokes announcement to leave EU according to Article 50: 5% With regards to the probability of downgrade, I assumed that in a no-deal scenario, a downgrade is more likely to happen soon after the eventual Brexit date due to increased uncertainty and real negative impact on trade and businesses. In both deal scenarios, I see after 1 January 2020 as the most likely bucket, because the assumption that there will be a deal seems baked into the current rating already. There could still be a major shake up, but I see it that as less likely than a wait-and-see.
So, given the above scenarios, I assign the following probabilities to the buckets:
a) 0%, 10%, 20%, 70%
b) 20%, 60%. 20%, 0%
c) 0%, 5%, 10%, 85%
d) 5%, 15%, 60%, 20%
e) 5%, 32%, 32%, 31% (this one is a bit of a wildcard, really not sure how to forecast what might happen if the UK revoked their announcement to leave the EU)  Adding up the branch probabilities gets me to the forecast.

Downgrade is almost certain in the "hard landing" scenario (no deal before 3/29/19). I think the likelihood of a hard landing depends on whether May's government survives the no confidence vote in early Jan. If the one cancelled earlier this month is any sign, I don't think she will. In that scenario, I see three outcomes - probability each outcome is first, probability of downgrade in ():
1. hard landing as the new government takes a harder line and negotiations crumble 35% (95%)
2. deal passes smoothly, how exactly that deal will affect the UK economy is uncertain 50% (50%)
3. new gov does an about-face and decides to remain in the EU 15% (0%) Outcome #3 would make me weight the 4th option (not before 1/1/20) more heavily
Outcome #2 would likely push a downgrade until after the deadline (3/30/19 - 12/31/19)
Outcome #1 would suggest a downgrade before 3/30/19 Based on the above-analysis, which is far from complete, my probabilities are as follows:
- before 3/20/19: 33%
- 3/20 - 7/3: 25%
- 8/1 - 12/31: 25%
- after 1/1/20: 17%
The cutoff for this seems too far out.
